24902777.trustfund:
TF099323-Supervision of Spanish Fund for
            Latin America and the Caribbean (SFLAC),TF097760-Building Resilience of the poor

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Strengthening Social Resilience to
            Climate Change Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Strengthening Social
            Resilience to Climate Change Project for Mexico were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: sustained engagement on the
            part of the Bank is critical to effectively support reform
            processes over the medium and long term. The Bank's
            support program has also included credit enhancement,
            hedging swaps, catastrophe risk management, and advisory
            services to support the evolution of the government's
            climate program through the years in a consistent manner.
            National Institute for Ecology and Climate Change (Instituto
            Nacional de Ecologia y Cambio Climatico) (INECC) recognized
            the positive impact of development policy loan (DPL) for
            encouraging the strengthening of social resilience, as there
            is still a gap in assessing the social impacts of climate
            change, and most climate change planning instruments tend to
            focus primarily on mitigation. As a coordinator of state
            climate change action programs and municipal climate action
            plans, INECC should emphasize the importance of focusing on
            adaptation measures, establishing clear actions with the
            institutions that are responsible for them, defining
            indicators with baseline values and goals, and including a
            description of their monitoring and evaluation (M and E)
            systems. The creation of stakeholder forums at the national
            and subnational level presents an opportunity to share
            information and generate feedback on adaptation measures.
            The operation's policy content and prior actions should
            reflect the Borrower's own program and priorities
            developed with the benefit of a national policymaking
            process that involves broad public consultation. Prior
            actions should be limited to a few key policy and
            institutional reforms. During the program preparation it is
            important to define indicators to which the federal
            government is committed as part of their existing programs
            and initiatives. Given the innovative nature of the actions
            supported, a DPL was the most appropriate financing
            instrument. One of the challenges related to focusing on
            institutional arrangements is the longer term and indirect
            impact on the goal of shared prosperity and eliminating extreme.

18550618.trustfund:
TF096061-Mexico - SFLAC Grant for
            Promoting a Multi-sectoral Multi-stakeholder A,TF097760-Building Resilience of the poor
            to Disaster and Climate Risk in Mexico,TF099323-Supervision of Spanish Fund for
            Latin America and the Caribbean (SFLAC)
18550618.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Urban development,Rural development,Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!: The social dimensions of climate change in Mexico

abstracts.cdata!:
Despite facing more extensive climatic
            events and significant losses, more resilient and/or
            affluent communities recover faster than poor and vulnerable
            communities exposed to minor disasters. This study
            identifies the key factors that explain these socio-spatial
            differences in terms of resilience and vulnerability to
            climate change, along with public policy options at
            different levels of government to strengthen resilience and
            reduce the vulnerability of poor households in exposed
            areas. The study addresses three key questions regarding the
            social factors that explain vulnerability to climate change:
            (1) Who is vulnerable and where they are located; (2) How
            will climate change affect welfare (income and nutrition) of
            vulnerable households in Mexico; and (3) What public
            policies and institutional reforms can strengthen the
            resilience of the most vulnerable social groups in the most
            exposed areas? The study is mainly based on a spatial and
            temporal analysis of secondary data from various sources
            that capture aspects of exposure in the city and home,
            sensitivity and adaptive capacity to climate change.

repnme.cdata!:
United Mexican States - Strengthening
            social resilience to climate change development policy loan
            : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
Directors expressed support for the
            strengthening social resilience to climate change
            development policy loan to provide recognition for and
            continue engagement with the implementation of climate
            change policies that strengthen Mexico's adaptive
            capacity and protection of the most vulnerable populations.
            Directors encouraged the Bank to systematize the lessons
            learned through the extensive and comprehensive engagement
            on climate change and share it with other countries.
            Finally, Directors stressed continued dialogue with
            interested stakeholders and collaboration with other donors.

15824222.trustfund:
TF096061-Mexico - SFLAC Grant for

0.cdata!:
Mexico - Fortalecimiento de la
            resiliencia social al cambio climático

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Strengthening Social Resilience to
            Climate Change Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Strengthening
            Social Resilience to Climate Change Project for Mexico is to
            strengthen social resilience to climate change through
            policies that will directly and indirectly benefit the poor
            by improving: (a) adaptation planning oriented to the state
            level; (b) disaster risk reduction and territorial
            development actions oriented to the municipal level; and (c)
            sustainable community forest management at the community
            level. This development policy loan will focus on the
            following areas: (1) Long term adaptation planning. Number
            of States designed Climate Change Action Programs during
            2012 that have included specific measures to promote civil
            society participation in the design of social resilience
            initiatives. (2) Disaster risk management and sustainable
            territorial development. (3) Sustainable community forest management.

Mexico - Strengthening Social Resilience to
